awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Coherent Computational Imaging: Micro Measurements in a Macro World
awd_abstract_narration:
This project is building fundamentally new types of cameras that combine novel optics and algorithm design to overcome the diffraction limit for macroscopic scenes, achieving unprecedented levels of precision in image, depth, and material acquisition. This project improves computer vision tasks performed on images of distant objects, increasing precision for applications such as surveillance, remote sensing, robot navigation, and autonomous vehicles. In addition, the work has direct applications in ongoing art conservation efforts to non-destructively acquire microscopic surface details of paintings and drawings. The research program is also tightly integrated with a comprehensive education program incorporating imaging and photography. The research team is developing curriculum for Chicago afterschool programs to introduce at-risk youth to basic concepts in optics, electronics, electrodynamics, and image processing. 

The focus of this research is to increase the level of detail that can be recovered when imaging macroscopic objects at large distances. The research is based on a wave-model of light with computational photography. This new theory of coherent light transport incorporates even the most complex effects of visual appearance such as participating media, sub-surface-scattering, multiple-bounce inter-reflections, diffraction, and interference. The research team is developing theory, hardware, and algorithms that lead to fundamental improvements in image, shape, and material acquisition for computer vision applications. The project is developing fundamentally new types of cameras for computer vision that rely on a synergistic combination of coherent optics (both active and passive) and novel algorithm design to overcome the diffraction limit. This project is constructing computational cameras that can resolve scene details well below the diffraction limit.

por.por_cntn:
The PI and his team developed theory, hardware and algorithms that lead to fundamental improvements in image, shape, and material acquisition for computer vision applications. He constructed computational cameras that can resolve scene details well below the diffraction limit. The research program enables improved computer vision tasks performed on images of distant objects, increasing precision for applications such as surveillance, remote sensing, robot navigation, and autonomous vehicles. In addition, the work has direct applications in ongoing art conservation efforts to non-destructively acquire microscopic surface details of paintings and drawings.

The prototype coherent camera array demonstrated by the PI and his team under this program has much as an 8x increase in resolution over the diffraction limit, achieving near 10um resolution at 1 meter standoff distances. The PI clearly demonstrated a path towards imaging beyond the diffraction limit, opening new opportunities for computer vision applications such as face recognition at unprecedented standoff distances. In addition, the PI demonstrated the first working prototype of macroscopic Fourier Ptychogrphy systems for diffusely reflecting objects.

The PI also developed a new method for remote digital holography using the SHI-ToF measurement technique that allows us to capture Time-of-flight imagery using modulation frequencies from 1MHz-1THz. The PI and his team used their Synthetic Wavelength Holography technique to develop a theory on the physical limits of looking through densely scattering media. The PI's team has shown in experiments that the SWH principle is a novel solution to the problem of imaging spatial contrast in reflectivity at wavelengths that are highly susceptible to random optical path length fluctuations caused by multiple-scattering. The fundamental limits in achieving this goal can be readily understood by applying small variations to well-established physical limits in holographic imaging. The lateral resolution of a digital hologram is given by the Abbe resolution limit relative to the optical wavelength. For a synthetic wavelength hologram, the lateral resolution is given by the Abbe limit relative to the synthetic wavelength.  The PI and his team have demonstrated experimentally that  for synthetic wavelength holography, the aberration condition is largely relaxed so that the OPD only has to be small relative to the synthetic wavelength.

In addition, as part of this program, the PI and his team applied the acquisition of light transport and hyperspectral images to surface shape and appearance acquisition of significant works of art, clearly demonstrating a significant benefit to the art conservation community in three specific studies (in collaboration with the Art Institute of Chicago, the Phoebe Hearst Museum, and the Georgia O?Keeffe Museum). Our collaborations with the Art Institute of Chicago and the Phoebe Hearst Museum have led to new developments in the fields of Conservation Science and Art History. Our work on the surface studies of the art of Paul Gauguin has given new insight into the process used to make many of his graphic works. Our hyperspectral imaging studies of the Fayum Mummy portraits at the Phoebe Hearst Musuem has given new insight into the materials used to produce these ancient artifacts. Our work with the Georgia O'Keeffe Museum has provided new insight, analysis, and algorithms on the formation of harmful soap pustules in paintings, informing new techniques for treatment and conservation of these artifacts. Our new XRF image fusion algorithms allow elemental chemical information to be captured non-invasively of art works at much higher acquisition speeds, widening applicability to Museum documentation and analysis.

Lastly, the PI and his team have developed a system that allows for the three-dimensional measurement of extended specular surfaces with high surface normal variations. It consists only of a mobile handheld device (such as a tablet) and exploits screen and front camera for Deflectometry-based surface measurements. High quality surface measurements are possible without the need for an offline calibration procedure. To compensate for the small screen of a mobile device, a multi-view registration technique is applied so that large surfaces can be densely reconstructed in their entirety. The mobile Deflectometry project is a first step towards a self-calibrating measurement procedure capable of taking 3D surface measurements in the wild and accessible to users with little to no technical imaging experience

The program supported in part four postdoctoral researchers, six PhD students, and three PhD thesis were published based on the research conducted. The program resulted in 36 publications in peer reviewed conferences and journals, and 4 patents filed.
